bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 20, 1922

div1.p: Carter discusses the latest yellow fever outbreak in Mexico. He is also concerned about the new cases in Africa.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 30, 1922
div1.p:
Your letter of the 28 inst. and enclosures re-
ceived. Referring to White's letter of the 17th: In
very obviously the data therein is not sufficient to
justify even an opinion as to the origin of the
y. fever reported at Panuco.

It is true, I think, that for y. f. to exist in a moderate-
sized circumscribed rural community, with-
out immigration thereto for 18 or even 6 months
should be practically impossible for the first figure -18 mons- any way. I know of no
authentic instance of it having done so & of a
number in which it died out. To do so would re-
quire very special conditions of travel in such
community. These of course could so occur-though
in fact they do not so as to havemakecause the infection to last
a long time, but in nature they have not
done so.

If the infection was entirely eliminated from
a community at any time obviously it could not
only return as White implies, by a reintroduction - not necessarily
by ship
2
by ship however. The fact that stegomyia work was
going on at some places implies that, from an administrative
standpoint at least, either (a) the existence of infec-
tion at these phacesplaces - where this work was being done- or
(b) the introduction of infection into theseem places was
considered as possibility. Infection either ex-
isting in or introduced into, the district in which the
men in question lived,- with its 55% from index
of stegomyia & many susceptible people - would be
apt to propagate.

So far as the general explation explanation of the re-
ports of y. fever under the circumstances Dr White
indicated as concerned; I discussed themit, rather briefly it may be, in a
letter to Caldwell on his case at San Cristobal (I think
it was) in March which White has doubtless seen.
Me Some mostly(?)(most?) of them themsuch cases have been, I think,
mistaken diagnoses; others from infection reintro-
duced: others or which had not been entirely the
eliminated it had been occurring without
having been recognized.

It is true that y. f. (in a fairly-well immunized com-
community
3
community any way) has always practically ceased to
occur within 6 weeks or 2 months after good
control of stegomyia production; (breeding places).
This interval should then about mark the du-
ration of life of the infected insect under
natural conditions. Neverthe theless there is al-
ways the possibility of one of them living as
long as Guiteras' caged insect - 157 days - and
then infecting a man.

I would be very glad to have an opportunity to
talk over these matters with you and Dr White & yourself on his
return to the U. S.: when, naturally, there will be
more definite data to discuss.

I am extremely sorry for the African news. I have no
papers with me & do not know whether Grande Bassam
is in Senegal or the Gulf of Guinea. There was an epi-
demic spirechetosis reported in upper Senegal in
1921- which (by Noc & Noguc') - not considered as
y. fever - a Fievre Recurrente.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours H. R. Carter Fy/
Over - Over.

hence my so-difficult-to-decypher-script. I leave
